questions.question_text: Which philosopher's 1690 Essay Concerning Human Understanding is often credited with introducing the modern concept of consciousness?

options.A: Immanuel Kant, who defined consciousness as the transcendental unity of apperception underlying all possible experience.
options.B: Rene Descartes, who defined consciousness as the indubitable certainty of one's own existence as a thinking substance.
options.C: John Locke, who defined consciousness as the perception of what passes in one's own mind.
options.D: David Hume, who defined consciousness as the continuous stream of impressions and ideas flowing through experience.

questions.question_text: In the free will debate, what position do compatibilists hold about the relationship between free will and determinism?

options.A: That free will requires indeterminism, meaning people can act freely only if some events are genuinely random.
options.B: That free will is an illusion of determinism, meaning people merely feel free while events are causally determined.
options.C: That free will is incompatible with determinism, meaning people cannot act freely if events are causally determined.
options.D: That free will is compatible with determinism, meaning people can act freely even if events are causally determined.

questions.question_text: Which philosopher is most associated with formulating the mind-body problem through his substance dualism in the 17th century?

options.A: Gottfried Leibniz, who proposed that mind and body are fundamentally independent substances in pre-established harmony.
options.B: Rene Descartes, who proposed that mind and body are fundamentally distinct substances that causally interact.
options.C: Thomas Hobbes, who proposed that mind and body are fundamentally reducible to mechanical motions of matter.
options.D: Baruch Spinoza, who proposed that mind and body are fundamentally identical attributes of one single substance.

questions.question_text: How did Aristotle's view of the soul differ from Plato's in ancient Greek philosophy?

options.A: Aristotle saw the soul as existing before birth in a realm of ideals, while Plato considered the soul arising only at conception.
options.B: Aristotle saw the soul as the form of a living body inseparable from it, while Plato considered the soul incorporeal and immortal.
options.C: Aristotle saw the soul as a divine spark imprisoned within matter, while Plato considered the soul a natural biological function.
options.D: Aristotle saw the soul as composed of indivisible atoms of consciousness, while Plato considered the soul a harmony of bodily elements.

questions.question_text: According to William James's influential theory, what is the relationship between bodily changes and emotions?

options.A: Emotions are cognitive appraisals that precede any bodily response to an exciting event, and physical changes are merely incidental aftereffects.
options.B: Bodily changes directly follow perception of an exciting event, and our feeling of those changes as they occur is the emotion.
options.C: Emotions arise first as mental judgments about an exciting event, and the bodily changes follow later as physical expressions of feeling.
options.D: Bodily changes and emotional feelings occur simultaneously and independently from an exciting event, connected only by parallel neural pathways.

questions.question_text: In the philosophy of perception, what does direct realism claim about our perceptual experience of objects?

options.A: That we perceive only our own mental states as internal phenomena, rather than having any access to external physical objects.
options.B: That we directly perceive external objects themselves, rather than mental representations or internal copies of those objects.
options.C: That we construct external objects entirely from sensory data, rather than encountering any mind-independent reality beyond those objects.
options.D: That we indirectly perceive external objects through mental intermediaries, rather than having unmediated contact with those objects.

questions.question_text: What is the key distinction between declarative memory and procedural memory in philosophy and cognitive science?

options.A: Declarative memory stores short-term sensory impressions briefly, while procedural memory stores long-term emotional associations and affective responses permanently.
options.B: Declarative memory stores unconscious motor habits and reflexes, while procedural memory stores explicit facts and consciously recalled personal events.
options.C: Declarative memory stores factual information and events, while procedural memory stores skills and knowledge of how to perform actions.
options.D: Declarative memory stores inherited instinctual behavioral patterns, while procedural memory stores culturally transmitted linguistic rules and social conventions.

questions.question_text: In philosophy of mind, what is the difference between an occurrent belief and a dispositional belief?

options.A: An occurrent belief is one that is true and justified, while a dispositional belief is one that is false but strongly felt.
options.B: An occurrent belief is one actively entertained in conscious thought, while a dispositional belief is held without currently being thought about.
options.C: An occurrent belief is one shared by an entire community, while a dispositional belief is one held privately by a single individual.
options.D: An occurrent belief is one inherited through biological evolution, while a dispositional belief is acquired through individual learning and social experience.

questions.question_text: According to David Hume, what is the relationship between desire and reason in motivating human action?

options.A: Reason alone cannot motivate action; it serves only to identify means to ends that are set by desire and passion.
options.B: Reason and desire jointly originate action; neither can function independently because both are required to set and pursue any goal.
options.C: Desire alone cannot motivate action; it serves only to provide energy for goals that are set by reason and judgment.
options.D: Reason directly overrides desire in action; it serves to suppress passions and replace them with rationally determined moral obligations.

questions.question_text: In philosophy, how does the narrow sense of 'thought' differ from its broad sense?

options.A: Narrowly, thought refers to linguistic verbal communication like speaking and writing; broadly, it includes all social interactions, verbal or nonverbal.
options.B: Narrowly, thought refers to sensory perceptual experiences like seeing and hearing; broadly, it includes all neural activity, cortical or subcortical.
options.C: Narrowly, thought refers to conscious conceptual processes like judging and reasoning; broadly, it includes all mental processes, conscious or unconscious.
options.D: Narrowly, thought refers to unconscious automatic reflexes like breathing and blinking; broadly, it includes all behavioral responses, voluntary or involuntary.

questions.question_text: What common mental phenomenon occurs during sleep and has been described by philosophers as evidence that the brain alone is sufficient to generate consciousness, without external sensory input?

options.A: Meditation
options.B: Sleepwalking
options.C: Dreaming
options.D: Hypnosis

questions.question_text: In his 1950 paper 'Computing Machinery and Intelligence,' Alan Turing proposed a test to address what fundamental philosophical question about machines?

options.A: Whether robots possess moral agency
options.B: Whether computers have free will
options.C: Whether machines can feel emotions
options.D: Whether machines can think

questions.question_text: What philosophical problem asks what makes a person at one time the same individual as a person at another time, addressing the conditions for persistence through change?

options.A: The problem of mental causation
options.B: The problem of other minds
options.C: The problem of bodily continuity
options.D: The problem of personal identity

questions.question_text: Rene Descartes argued that mind and body are fundamentally distinct substances, with the mind being a nonphysical 'thinking thing' (res cogitans). What is this philosophical position called?

options.A: Neutral monism
options.B: Property monism
options.C: Substance dualism
options.D: Reductive physicalism

questions.question_text: What philosophical position, dominant among contemporary philosophers of mind, holds that everything that exists is ultimately physical and that mental states supervene on physical states?

options.A: Physicalism
options.B: Functionalism
options.C: Neutral monism
options.D: Epiphenomenalism

questions.question_text: In philosophy of mind, what term refers to the subjective, felt qualities of conscious experience, such as the redness of red or the specific taste of wine?

options.A: Percepts
options.B: Noumena
options.C: Sensa
options.D: Qualia

questions.question_text: Which theory in philosophy of mind defines mental states not by their internal composition but by their causal relations to sensory inputs, behavioral outputs, and other mental states?

options.A: Property dualism
options.B: Functionalism
options.C: Type physicalism
options.D: Behaviorism

questions.question_text: Franz Brentano proposed that all mental phenomena are distinguished from physical phenomena by their 'directedness' toward an object. What is this property of mental states called?

options.A: Phenomenality
options.B: Intentionality
options.C: Representationality
options.D: Reflexivity

questions.question_text: What philosophical approach to mind holds that mental states are nothing more than behavioral dispositions, so that being in pain simply means being disposed to wince, moan, or seek relief?

options.A: Analytical phenomenology
options.B: Psychological functionalism
options.C: Eliminative materialism
options.D: Philosophical behaviourism

questions.question_text: What theory in philosophy of mind asserts that types of mental states, such as pain, are strictly identical to types of brain states, such as C-fiber firings?

options.A: Type identity theory
options.B: Token physicalism theory
options.C: Functional state theory
options.D: Neural correlate theory

questions.question_text: Type physicalism, also known as the mind-brain identity theory, identifies types of mental states with types of brain states. Who developed this theory as a direct reaction to the failure of which earlier approach?

options.A: J.J.C. Smart and Ullin Place developed it as a reaction to behaviourism
options.B: Donald Davidson and Jaegwon Kim developed it as a reaction to epiphenomenalism
options.C: Hilary Putnam and Jerry Fodor developed it as a reaction to dualism
options.D: Paul Churchland and Daniel Dennett developed it as a reaction to functionalism

questions.question_text: Eliminative materialism claims that common-sense mental state categories such as beliefs and desires do not actually exist. Which two philosophers have been most influential in advancing this radical position?

options.A: Paul Churchland and Patricia Churchland
options.B: David Chalmers and Frank Jackson
options.C: Jerry Fodor and Ned Block
options.D: Daniel Dennett and Hilary Putnam

questions.question_text: In philosophy of mind, what does the term 'folk psychology' refer to, and what are the two main mental state concepts it employs to explain human behaviour?

options.A: The evolutionary account of cognition explained through instincts and reflexes
options.B: The ordinary, intuitive framework people use to explain behaviour through beliefs and desires
options.C: The clinical framework therapists use to treat patients through drives and complexes
options.D: The scientific study of cultural traditions through observations and hypotheses

questions.question_text: The problem of mental causation asks how mental states can cause physical events. Which sub-problem, concerning whether mental causes are preempted by sufficient physical causes, has attracted the most philosophical attention?

options.A: The overdetermination problem
options.B: The explanatory gap problem
options.C: The causal exclusion problem
options.D: The interaction problem

questions.question_text: A philosophical zombie (p-zombie) is physically identical to a normal human but lacks one crucial feature. What does a p-zombie lack, and against which broad philosophical position is the thought experiment directed?

options.A: It lacks rational thought and is used as an argument against functionalism
options.B: It lacks free will and is used as an argument against compatibilism
options.C: It lacks conscious experience and is used as an argument against physicalism
options.D: It lacks linguistic ability and is used as an argument against behaviourism

questions.question_text: Ned Block drew an influential distinction between two kinds of consciousness. What does phenomenal consciousness refer to, as contrasted with access consciousness?

options.A: The capacity to deliberately monitor, regulate, and adjust one's own ongoing cognitive processes
options.B: The subjective, qualitative character of experience — what it is like to be in a mental state
options.C: The set of neural correlates of consciousness that can be detected through modern brain imaging
options.D: The ability to verbally report on and rationally reason about one's own internal mental states

questions.question_text: David Chalmers first articulated the 'hard problem of consciousness' in 1994. What distinguishes the hard problem from the so-called 'easy problems' of consciousness?

options.A: Easy problems describe sensory pathways; the hard problem asks how the brain stores long-term memories
options.B: Easy problems study unconscious processing; the hard problem asks why sleep is necessary for survival
options.C: Easy problems address brain anatomy; the hard problem asks how neurons generate electrical signals
options.D: Easy problems explain cognitive functions and behaviour; the hard problem asks why physical processes produce subjective experience

questions.question_text: In John Searle's 1980 Chinese room thought experiment, a person follows English instructions to manipulate Chinese symbols without understanding Chinese. What philosophical conclusion does Searle draw from this scenario?

options.A: That language translation requires at least two fluent speakers to achieve successful communication
options.B: That syntactic symbol manipulation alone is insufficient for genuine semantic understanding or mind
options.C: That computers can achieve real understanding provided they are given sufficiently detailed programming
options.D: That only biological neural networks are capable of producing any form of intelligent output

questions.question_text: Hilary Putnam argued in the 1960s that the same mental state can be realised by different physical substrates, using examples such as humans, aliens, and robots all feeling pain. What is this thesis called, and which theory does it primarily challenge?

options.A: Anomalous monism; it challenges property dualism, which posits non-physical mental properties alongside physical ones
options.B: Functionalism; it challenges eliminative materialism, which denies the existence of mental states entirely
options.C: Neutral monism; it challenges substance dualism, which separates mind and body into distinct substances
options.D: Multiple realizability; it challenges type identity theory, which equates mental types with specific brain state types

questions.question_text: Donald Davidson introduced the concept of supervenience to philosophy of mind in his 1970 essay 'Mental Events'. How is the supervenience of the mental on the physical typically formulated?

options.A: There cannot be a mental difference between two entities without a corresponding physical difference
options.B: Every mental property is numerically identical to exactly one specific physical property
options.C: Mental states are causally inert byproducts that always accompany physical processes
options.D: Physical laws can be directly translated into psychological laws without any residue

questions.question_text: How does token physicalism differ from type physicalism regarding the relationship between mental and physical events?

options.A: Token physicalism holds that each particular mental event is caused by some physical event, but affirms a systematic type-to-type mapping between mental and physical kinds.
options.B: Token physicalism holds that each particular mental event is reducible to one specific physical event type, and affirms a strict type-to-type law between mental and physical kinds.
options.C: Token physicalism holds that each particular mental event is identical to some physical event, but denies a systematic type-to-type mapping between mental and physical kinds.
options.D: Token physicalism holds that each particular mental event is independent of any physical event, but accepts a systematic type-to-type correlation between mental and physical kinds.

questions.question_text: According to higher-order thought theory, what condition must be met for a mental state to be conscious?

options.A: The mental state must be the object of a higher-order thought, meaning the subject must have a thought that represents that first-order mental state.
options.B: The mental state must be the result of a deliberate intention, meaning the subject must form a plan that consciously initiates that first-order mental state.
options.C: The mental state must be the product of a sensory stimulus, meaning the subject must receive an input that directly generates that first-order mental state.
options.D: The mental state must be the cause of a behavioral response, meaning the subject must produce an action that expresses that first-order mental state.

questions.question_text: In the Otto and Inga thought experiment by Clark and Chalmers, what does Otto's notebook illustrate about cognition?

options.A: That external objects like a notebook can function as part of a cognitive process, extending the mind beyond the brain and body into the environment.
options.B: That external objects like a notebook can replace biological memory entirely, eliminating the need for any neural processing in the brain and body.
options.C: That external objects like a notebook can record information passively, but never participate as genuine components of cognition in the brain and body.
options.D: That external objects like a notebook can simulate conscious experience artificially, creating a second mind independent of the brain and body altogether.

questions.question_text: What does strong representationalism claim about the relationship between phenomenal character and intentional content?

options.A: Strong representationalism claims that phenomenal character merely causes or produces intentional content, so all representational differences originate from phenomenal differences.
options.B: Strong representationalism claims that phenomenal character reduces to or is identical with intentional content, so all phenomenal differences are representational differences.
options.C: Strong representationalism claims that phenomenal character supervenes on but never reduces to intentional content, so some phenomenal differences lack any representational basis.
options.D: Strong representationalism claims that phenomenal character is independent of and unrelated to intentional content, so phenomenal differences never correlate with representational ones.

questions.question_text: What did Hilary Putnam's Twin Earth thought experiment aim to demonstrate about mental content?

options.A: That the meaning and content of mental states are wholly determined by social and linguistic conventions, not by any causal connection to the world of the thinker.
options.B: That the meaning and content of mental states are partly determined by external environmental factors, not solely by the internal physical states of the thinker.
options.C: That the meaning and content of mental states are entirely determined by internal neurological structures, not influenced by the external physical environment of the thinker.
options.D: That the meaning and content of mental states are fully determined by behavioral dispositions and responses, not by any subjective inner experience of the thinker.

questions.question_text: What position does epiphenomenalism take on the causal relationship between mental and physical events?

options.A: Epiphenomenalism holds that neither mental nor physical events cause the other, with both types arising independently from a shared underlying neutral substance.
options.B: Epiphenomenalism holds that physical events cause mental events, but mental events are causally inert byproducts that have no causal influence on physical events.
options.C: Epiphenomenalism holds that mental events cause physical events, but physical events are causally inert byproducts that have no causal influence on mental events.
options.D: Epiphenomenalism holds that mental and physical events cause each other reciprocally, with both types exerting equal and symmetric causal influence on one another.

questions.question_text: In Baars's global workspace theory, what mechanism explains how information becomes conscious?

options.A: Information becomes conscious when it is filtered and restricted to a single specialized brain module via a local workspace, making it available for focused processing.
options.B: Information becomes conscious when it is selected and broadcast widely across multiple specialized brain modules via a global workspace, making it available for diverse processing.
options.C: Information becomes conscious when it is stored and consolidated in long-term memory circuits via a hippocampal workspace, making it available for future retrieval.
options.D: Information becomes conscious when it is generated and projected from prefrontal cortex alone via a top-down workspace, making it available for executive processing.

questions.question_text: In Tononi's integrated information theory, what does the quantity phi measure and why is it significant for consciousness?

options.A: Phi measures the amount of integrated information generated by a system, and the theory identifies this quantity with the level of consciousness a system possesses.
options.B: Phi measures the total number of synaptic connections within a system, and the theory identifies this quantity with the computational power a system demonstrates.
options.C: Phi measures the speed of neural signal transmission across a system, and the theory identifies this quantity with the complexity of behavior a system produces.
options.D: Phi measures the degree of random neural activity throughout a system, and the theory identifies this quantity with the adaptability of responses a system exhibits.

questions.question_text: Davidson's anomalous monism combines three principles. Which combination accurately characterizes the position?

options.A: Mental events are distinct from physical events, all causation falls under strict laws, and there are strict psychophysical laws connecting mental and physical descriptions.
options.B: Mental events are identical to physical events, all causation falls under strict laws, but there are no strict psychophysical laws connecting mental and physical descriptions.
options.C: Mental events are distinct from physical events, causation does not require strict laws, but there are no strict psychophysical laws connecting mental and physical descriptions.
options.D: Mental events are identical to physical events, causation does not require strict laws, and there are strict psychophysical laws connecting mental and physical descriptions.

questions.question_text: What is the central claim of the phenomenal intentionality thesis, and how does it contrast with standard naturalist approaches to intentionality?

options.A: It claims that intentionality is produced by or derived from linguistic conventions, contrasting with naturalist views that reduce intentionality to evolutionary or adaptive functions alone.
options.B: It claims that intentionality is eliminated by or incompatible with phenomenal consciousness, contrasting with naturalist views that ground intentionality in subjective experiential qualities.
options.C: It claims that intentionality is independent of and unrelated to phenomenal consciousness, contrasting with naturalist views that deny any connection between intentionality and physical relations.
options.D: It claims that intentionality is grounded in or constituted by phenomenal consciousness, contrasting with naturalist views that reduce intentionality to causal or informational relations.

questions.question_text: Enactivism, as introduced by Varela, Thompson, and Rosch in 'The Embodied Mind' (1991), proposes an alternative to representationalist theories of cognition. What is its central claim about the nature of cognition?

options.A: Cognition is constituted through passive reception of environmental stimuli, which the brain then encodes as internal mental representations.
options.B: Cognition is constituted through computational symbol manipulation within neural circuits, not through sensory interaction with the environment.
options.C: Cognition is constituted through social and linguistic practices shared among agents, not through individual embodied interaction with the environment.
options.D: Cognition is constituted through embodied action and dynamic interaction with the environment, not through internal mental representations.

questions.question_text: Disjunctivism in the philosophy of perception rejects the 'common factor' assumption shared by sense-datum and representationalist theories. What does it claim about the relationship between veridical perception and hallucination?

options.A: Veridical perception and hallucination are both forms of indirect representation differing only in the reliability of the causal chain.
options.B: Veridical perception and hallucination are identical kinds of mental states that differ only in their external causal origins.
options.C: Veridical perception and hallucination are fundamentally different kinds of mental states, not experiences sharing a common experiential core.
options.D: Veridical perception and hallucination share a common sensory core but differ in whether higher-order cognitive endorsement is present.

questions.question_text: Derek Parfit's psychological continuity theory of personal identity updates Locke's memory-based account. What structural feature distinguishes Parfit's criterion from Locke's original theory?

options.A: Parfit requires that psychological connections be caused by an immaterial soul, rather than by neurological processes alone.
options.B: Parfit requires a single unbroken chain of conscious experiences persisting through time, rather than overlapping psychological connections.
options.C: Parfit requires physical continuity of the brain in addition to memory connections, rather than psychological connections alone.
options.D: Parfit requires overlapping chains of psychological connections including memory, intention, and character, rather than direct memory links alone.

questions.question_text: In the internalism-externalism debate about mental content, 'narrow content' was proposed as a response to Putnam's and Burge's externalist arguments. What defines narrow content?

options.A: Narrow content is mental content determined jointly by intrinsic states and the immediate physical environment surrounding the subject.
options.B: Narrow content is mental content determined by the linguistic community's conventions, remaining fixed across different physical realizers.
options.C: Narrow content is mental content that lacks truth conditions and therefore cannot play a role in rational inference or action.
options.D: Narrow content is mental content determined solely by a subject's intrinsic physical states, remaining the same regardless of environmental differences.

questions.question_text: Gareth Evans introduced the notion of nonconceptual content into analytic philosophy, and Christopher Peacocke developed it further. What is the core claim about perceptual experience that motivates this notion?

options.A: Perceptual experience is entirely conceptual but employs concepts so rapidly that the perceiver cannot introspect on them consciously.
options.B: The fine-grained richness of perceptual experience outstrips the perceiver's conceptual capacities, so perception represents aspects of the world without requiring corresponding concepts.
options.C: Perceptual experience is conceptually structured but draws on innate concepts that are never explicitly learned or articulated by the perceiver.
options.D: The coarse-grained nature of perceptual experience underdetermines conceptual content, so perception requires additional inferential reasoning to represent the world.

questions.question_text: Keith Frankish's illusionism about phenomenal consciousness is a revisionary position in philosophy of mind. What does illusionism claim, and what central explanatory challenge does it face?

options.A: It claims phenomenal properties are real but epiphenomenal and faces the problem of explaining how causally inert properties evolved by natural selection.
options.B: It claims phenomenal properties are socially constructed through shared linguistic practices and faces the problem of explaining cross-cultural agreement about basic qualitative sensory experiences.
options.C: It claims phenomenal properties are an introspective illusion and faces the 'illusion problem' of explaining why we are disposed to judge we are phenomenally conscious.
options.D: It claims phenomenal properties reduce to representational content and faces the problem of explaining why some representations feel qualitative while others do not.

questions.question_text: Frege's distinction between sense (Sinn) and reference (Bedeutung) has been applied to philosophy of mind to address puzzles about mental content. What puzzle does this distinction solve regarding identity statements?

options.A: It explains how 'Hesperus is Phosphorus' is a synthetic a priori truth while 'Hesperus is Hesperus' is analytic, since referents determine modal status.
options.B: It explains how 'Hesperus is Phosphorus' is necessarily false while 'Hesperus is Hesperus' is necessarily true, since each name has a unique referent.
options.C: It explains how 'Hesperus is Phosphorus' is empirically unverifiable while 'Hesperus is Hesperus' is analytically true, since sense determines verification method.
options.D: It explains how 'Hesperus is Phosphorus' is informative while 'Hesperus is Hesperus' is trivial, since co-referring terms can differ in their mode of presentation.

questions.question_text: William Lycan's higher-order perception (HOP) theory offers a specific account of what makes a mental state conscious. How does HOP theory differ from Rosenthal's higher-order thought (HOT) theory?

options.A: HOP holds that consciousness involves direct acquaintance with external objects, while HOT requires an inferential judgment about the first-order state.
options.B: HOP holds that consciousness involves quasi-perceptual inner sense monitoring of first-order states, while HOT requires a conceptual thought directed at the first-order state.
options.C: HOP holds that consciousness involves linguistic self-reports about first-order states, while HOT requires a non-conceptual sensory awareness of the first-order state.
options.D: HOP holds that consciousness involves global broadcast of first-order states to multiple brain areas, while HOT requires a localized prefrontal representation.

questions.question_text: The predictive processing framework, developed by Karl Friston and Andy Clark, offers a unified account of perception, action, and cognition. What is the core computational mechanism it proposes?

options.A: The brain accumulates bottom-up sensory evidence through feedforward layers, and perception is driven by maximizing the total activation of higher cortical areas.
options.B: The brain generates random hypotheses about sensory input at each level, and perception is driven by selecting the hypothesis with the highest posterior probability.
options.C: The brain stores templates of previously encountered stimuli, and perception is driven by matching incoming signals to the closest stored template.
options.D: The brain generates hierarchical top-down predictions about sensory input, and perception is driven by minimizing the prediction error between expectations and actual signals.

questions.question_text: Ned Block's influential 1995 distinction between access consciousness and phenomenal consciousness has shaped debates about the nature of conscious experience. What is Block's 'overflow' argument?

options.A: Phenomenal consciousness overflows into unconscious processing: conscious experience generates hidden cognitive states that influence behavior without any access.
options.B: Phenomenal consciousness overflows access consciousness: we can consciously experience more than what is available for reasoning, report, and rational control of action.
options.C: Access consciousness overflows phenomenal consciousness: we can rationally process and report on more information than we can consciously experience at once.
options.D: Phenomenal consciousness and access consciousness always co-occur: every phenomenally conscious state is simultaneously available for reasoning and verbal report.
